'''Patrick Paul Gelsinger''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɡ|ɛ|l|s|ɪ|ŋ|ɡ|ɚ}}; born March 5, 1961)<ref name=CHM /> is an American business executive and engineer, who was the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Intel]] from February 2021 to December 2024.<ref name="wsj1"/><ref name="cnbc-retirement"/><ref name="wsj-retirement"/>

Based mainly in [[Silicon Valley]] since the late 1970s, Gelsinger graduated from [[Stanford University]] with a master's degree in engineering in 1985 and was the chief architect of Intel's [[i486]] [[microprocessor]] in the 1980s. He was Intel's [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] from 2001 to 2009. He left Intel in 2009 and was the CEO of [[VMware]] and president and chief operating officer (COO) at [[EMC Corporation|EMC]], before returning to Intel as CEO in February 2021.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last1=Valinsky |first1=Jordan |last2=Duffy |first2=Clare |date=January 13, 2021 |title=Intel ousts CEO and names successor |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/13/investing/intel-new-ceo-pat-gelsinger/index.html|website=CNN |language=en-US |access-date=January 14, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Note from Pat Gelsinger to Intel |url=https://newsroom.intel.com/news/note-from-pat-gelsinger-to-intel/ |website=Intel Newsroom |language=en-US |access-date=January 14, 2021}}</ref> In 2024, he stepped down as the CEO and from the board of directors.<ref name="wsj-retirement" />

== Early life and education ==
Gelsinger was raised on family farms by his parents, June and Paul Gelsinger, in rural [[Robesonia]], in an [[Amish]] and [[Mennonite]] part of [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name=CHM>{{cite web |last1=Brock |first1=David C. |last2=Fairbairn |first2=Doug |date=January 9, 2019 |title=Oral History of Pat Gelsinger |url=https://archive.computerhistory.org/resources/access/text/2019/06/102781029-05-01-acc.pdf |website=Computer History |language=en-US |access-date=August 31, 2021}}</ref><ref name=MCALL/> As a teenager, he received a high score on a [[Lincoln Technical Institute|Lincoln Tech]] electronics technology test, winning an early-admission scholarship. He then skipped his final year at Conrad Weiser High School and left home at 16 for college. There he earned the remainder of high school credits for graduation and worked at [[WFMZ-TV]] Channel 69 as a technician,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Anthes |first1=Gary |date=June 5, 2008 |title=The Grill: Intel's Patrick Gelsinger on the hot seat |url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2535121/the-grill--intel-s-patrick-gelsinger-on-the-hot-seat.html |work=Computer World |access-date=31 August 2021}}</ref> while obtaining an associate’s degree from Lincoln Tech in [[West Orange, New Jersey|West Orange]], [[New Jersey]]<ref name="Pressman 2021">{{cite news |last1=Pressman |first1=Aaron |date=January 13, 2021 |title=Who is Intel's new CEO, Pat Gelsinger |url=https://fortune.com/2021/01/13/intel-new-ceo-pat-gelsinger-replacing-bob-swan/ |work=Fortune |language=en-US |access-date=January 15, 2021}}</ref> in 1979. 

In 1979, at age 18, he moved to [[Silicon Valley]] to work at [[Intel]] as a quality-control technician.<ref name=MCALL/><ref name="Forbes 06-15">{{Cite web |last=Karlgaard |first=Rich |date=June 28, 2016 |title=Serial Bloomer: Pat Gelsinger |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richkarlgaard/2016/06/15/serial-bloomer-pat-gelsinger/ |website=Forbes |language=en-US |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref><ref name=CHM/> While at Intel, he earned a bachelor's degree in [[electrical engineering]], graduating [[magna cum laude]]<ref name=EXIM/> from [[Santa Clara University]] in 1983, and then earned a master's degree in electrical engineering and [[computer science]] from [[Stanford University]] in 1985.<ref name="Pressman 2021"/>

== Career ==
[[File:80486dx2-large.jpg|thumb|260x260px|An Intel 486DX2 microprocessor using the [[i486|80486 architecture]] designed by Gelsinger in the 1980s]]
Gelsinger first joined Intel at 18 years old in 1979 just after earning an associate degree from Lincoln Tech.<ref name="Pressman 2021"/> He spent much of his career with the company in Oregon,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rogoway |first1=Mike |date=February 14, 2021 |title=With new CEO Pat Gelsinger, Intel looks to its past in hopes of securing the future |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/silicon-forest/2021/02/with-new-ceo-pat-gelsinger-intel-looks-to-its-past-in-hopes-of-securing-the-future.html |work=Oregon Live |access-date=August 31, 2021}}</ref> where he maintains a home.<ref name=moneyinc/> In 1987, he co-authored his first book about programming the [[80386]] [[microprocessor]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Crawford |first1=John H. |author1-link=John Crawford (engineer) |last2=Gelsinger |first2=Patrick P. |year=1987 |title=Programming the 80386 |url=https://archive.org/details/programming8038600craw |location=San Francisco, CA |publisher=Sybex Inc |lccn=87061199 |isbn=978-0-89588-381-0}}</ref><ref name="Intel">{{Cite web |title=Pat Gelsinger: A journey back home |url=https://newsroom.intel.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2021/02/pat-gelsinger-timeline-58375621.pdf |website=Intel Newsroom |language=en-US |access-date=March 15, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210215143137/https://newsroom.intel.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2021/02/pat-gelsinger-timeline-58375621.pdf |archive-date=February 15, 2021 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Gelsinger was the lead architect of the 4th generation [[Intel 80486|80486]] processor<ref name="Intel"/> introduced in 1989.<ref name="Pressman 2021"/> At age 32, he was named the youngest vice president in Intel's history.<ref name=MCALL/> Mentored by Intel CEO [[Andrew Grove]], Gelsinger became the company's [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] in 2001, leading key technology developments, including [[Wi-Fi]], [[USB]], [[Intel Core]] and [[Intel Xeon]] processors, and 14 chip projects.<ref name=SIA>{{cite web |title=Board of Directors Patrick Gelsinger |url=https://www.semiconductors.org/board/patrick-gelsinger/ |website=Semiconductor Industry Association |date=June 2018 |access-date=August 31, 2021}}</ref><ref name="Mercury News">{{Cite web |last=Robertson |first=Jordan |date=September 14, 2009 |title=Executive shuffle at Intel: Pat Gelsinger leaves to join EMC |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2009/09/14/executive-shuffle-at-intel-pat-gelsinger-leaves-to-join-emc/ |website=The Mercury News |language=en-US |access-date=August 6, 2019}}</ref> He launched the [[Intel Developer Forum]] conference as a counterpart to [[Microsoft]]'s [[Windows Hardware Engineering Conference|WinHEC]].

In September 2009, he left Intel to join EMC as president and chief operating officer.<ref name="Mercury News"/> In 2012, he became the CEO of [[VMware]].<ref name="SIA" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Sozzi |first=Brian |date=May 23, 2022 |title=Intel CEO weighs in on Broadcom's potential blockbuster deal for VMware |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/intel-ceo-broadcom-vmware-162038907.html |website=Yahoo! Finance |language=en-US |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220524043237/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/intel-ceo-broadcom-vmware-162038907.html |archive-date=May 24, 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Gelsinger rejoined Intel as their new CEO on February 15, 2021, after previously having a 30 year-long career at the company in various technical engineering and leadership roles.<ref>{{cite web |title=Intel Appoints Tech Industry Leader Pat Gelsinger as New CEO |url=https://newsroom.intel.com/news-releases/intel-appoints-tech-industry-leader-pat-gelsinger-as-new-ceo/ |website=Intel Newsroom |language=en-US |date=January 13, 2021 |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref><ref name="wsj1">{{cite news |last1=Fitch |first1=Asa |date=January 13, 2021 |title=Intel Ousts CEO Bob Swan |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-ceo-bob-swan-steps-down-11610548665 |work=The Wall Street Journal |language=en-US |access-date=14 January 2021}}</ref> This followed reorganization pressure, due to languishing share prices, from its newest activist investor [[Third Point Management]]. Gelsinger led Intel's course correction, including construction of two $20 billion Arizona manufacturing plants (fabs) for its planned expansion.<ref name=AnandTech>{{cite web |last1=Smith |first1=Ryan |date=March 17, 2021 |title=Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger To Host Webcast About Intel's Future On March 23rd |url=https://www.anandtech.com/show/16560/intel-ceo-pat-gelsinger-to-host-webcast-about-intels-future-on-march-23rd |website=AnandTech |language=en-US |access-date=September 1, 2021}}</ref><ref name=CRN>{{cite web |last1=Martin |first1=Dylan |date=July 23, 2021 |title=Gelsinger: Intel Will Expand Manufacturing, Make Chips For Others |url=https://www.crn.com/news/components-peripherals/gelsinger-intel-will-expand-manufacturing-make-chips-for-others |website=CRN |language=en-US |access-date=1 September 2021}}</ref><ref name=SEC>{{cite web |author1=Dell Incorporated |title=EMC Corporation |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/790070/000119312515342507/d16415d425.htm |website=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission |language=en-US |access-date=1 September 2021 |ref=Commission File No. 1-09853 |date=October 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name=BBC>{{cite news |last1=Kelion |first1=Leo |date=March 24, 2021 |title=Intel chief Pat Gelsinger: Too many chips made in Asia |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-56512430 |work=BBC News |language=en-GB |access-date=September 1, 2021}}</ref> Media reported positive responses to Gelsinger's appointment and credited the decision for driving Intel share prices up nearly 8%.<ref name="NYT 01-13">{{cite news |last1=Clark |first1=Don |last2=Lohr |first2=Steve |date=January 13, 2021 |title=Intel, Under Pressure to Rethink Its Business, Ousts Its Chief Executive |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/13/technology/intel-ceo-swan-gelsinger.html |location=San Francisco, CA |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |access-date=September 1, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cherney |first1=Max A. |date=January 13, 2021 |title=All the Problems Pat Gelsinger Faces as Intel's Next CEO |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/pat-gelsinger-is-the-right-ceo-for-intel-hes-got-many-problems-to-address-51610563584 |website=Barron's |access-date=September 1, 2021}}</ref> On March 23, 2021, Intel shares rose over 6% following Gelsinger’s remarks regarding company strategy.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Leswing |first1=Kif |date=March 23, 2021 |title='Intel is back:' New CEO's plan to make chips for other companies excites investors |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/23/intel-makes-foundry-strategy-shift-under-new-ceo-pat-gelsinger-.html |work=CNBC |language=en-US |access-date=1 September 2021}}</ref>

In May 2021, Gelsinger was interviewed by [[Lesley Stahl]] of ''[[60 Minutes]]''. Gelsinger stated that Intel plans to catch up with Taiwanese chip manufacturer [[TSMC]] and Korean chip manufacturer [[Samsung]] within the next five years. He announced a planned three and a half-billion dollar upgrade to Intel's [[List of Intel manufacturing sites|fab in New Mexico]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Stahl |first=Lesley |date=May 2, 2021 |title=Chip shortage highlights U.S. dependence on fragile supply chain |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/semiconductor-chip-shortage-60-minutes-2021-05-02/ |work=CBS News |language=en-US |access-date=28 August 2021}}</ref>

In March 2022, Gelsinger personally announced the start of an entirely new fab built for roughly $20 billion near [[Magdeburg]], [[Saxony-Anhalt]], [[Germany]] to employ 7,000 people during construction work and 3,000 people in production work in 2027.<ref>{{cite web|title=Intel spends $33 billion in Germany in landmark expansion|website=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/berlin-sign-agreement-with-intel-after-chip-plant-talks-2023-06-19/}}</ref>

On December 1, 2024, Gelsinger stepped down from the position of Intel CEO and from the company’s board of directors. CFO [[David Zinsner]] and executive [[Michelle Johnston Holthaus]] were named interim co-CEOs, while board member [[Frank Yeary]] assumed interim executive Chairship <ref name="cnbc-retirement">{{cite news |last1= |first1= |date=December 2, 2024 |title=Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger is out, stock up 5% |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2024/12/02/intel-ceo-pat-gelsinger-is-out.html |work=CNBC |language=en-US |access-date=2 December 2024}}</ref><ref name="wsj-retirement">{{cite news |last1= |first1= |date=December 2, 2024 |title=Intel CEO Gelsinger Retires, Leaves Board |url=https://www.wsj.com/tech/intel-ceo-gelsinger-retires-leaves-board-cb2478e6 |work=WSJ |language=en-US |access-date=2 December 2024}}</ref> as the company conducts a search for a permanent new CEO. Holthaus has also been named to the newly-created CEO of Intel products, which will oversee, among other things, its data center and AI product efforts.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Clare Duffy, David |date=2024-12-02 |title=Intel CEO resigns after a disastrous tenure {{!}} CNN Business |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/12/02/tech/intel-ceo-pat-gelsinger-resigns/index.html |access-date=2024-12-03 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>

== Honors and appointments ==
He was named a Fellow of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]] in 2008 and is a director of the [[Semiconductor Industry Association]] (SIA). He is a member of the National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee (NSTAC).<ref name=EXIM>{{cite web |title=Pat Gelsinger CEO, VMware |url=https://www.exim.gov/annual-conference/2020/bios/gelsinger-pat |website=Export-Import Bank of the United States |language=en-US |access-date=August 29, 2021}}</ref>

Gelsinger holds eight design patents, developed for communications, computer architecture and [[VLSI]] design.<ref name="Intel"/><ref name=EXIM/>

In 2021, Gelsinger was appointed to [[President of the United States|President]] [[Joe Biden]]'s [[President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology|Council of Advisors on Science and Technology]]. In this position, he has advised Biden on the [[2020–present global chip shortage|chips shortage]] and advocated for the passage of the [[CHIPS and Science Act]]. Gelsinger was a guest at Biden's [[State of the Union Address]] in March 2022.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Overfelt |first1=Maggie |date=March 2, 2022 |title=Why Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger was a guest at President Biden's State of the Union address |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/02/why-intels-ceo-was-a-guest-at-bidens-state-of-the-union-address.html |website=CNBC |language=en-US |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref> Biden has spoken in favor of Intel's investment in fabrication plants in the U.S. and has visited the $20 billion facility planned in [[Ohio]] alongside Gelsinger.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Makena |date=September 9, 2022 |title=President Joe Biden speaks after groundbreaking for Intel's $20 billion semiconductor plant |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/9/9/23344834/semiconductor-joe-biden-ohio-intel-gelsinger-chips-science-subsidies |website=The Verge |language=en-US |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref>

=== Honors ===
In October 2021, Gelsinger was inducted into [[Indiana Wesleyan University]]'s Society of World Changers. While speaking on campus, he received an honorary doctor of science degree and a bronze bust of Gelsinger was placed in the university's library rotunda. In 2022, he was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Engineering from [[Ohio State University]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger to be inducted as World Changer |url=https://www.indwes.edu/news/2021/10/intel-ceo-pat-gelsinger-to-be-inducted-as-world-changer |website=Indiana Wesleyan University |language=en-US |date=October 25, 2021 |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Gelsinger and his wife Linda<ref name=MCALL>{{cite news |last1=Savidge |first1=Mariella |date=January 23, 2000 |title=Berks Native Made It Big With Intel Patrick P. Gelsinger Was Architect of Chipmaker's 486 Processor. |url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-2000-01-23-3297824-story.html |work=The Morning Call |access-date=August 28, 2021}}</ref> are Christians<ref name="Fortune">{{cite web |last1=Karlsgaard |first1=Rich |date=June 28, 2016 |title=Serial Bloomer: Pat Gelsinger |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richkarlgaard/2016/06/15/serial-bloomer-pat-gelsinger/?sh=7ce2dd096bc5 |website=Fortune |language=en-US |access-date=May 12, 2021}}</ref> who "support multiple worthy causes", including sponsorship of [[disaster relief]] medical teams.<ref name=moneyinc>{{cite news |last1=Parker |first1=Garrett |date=January 12, 2018 |title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Pat Gelsinger |url=https://moneyinc.com/10-things-didnt-know-pat-gelsinger/ |work=Money, Inc |language=en-US |access-date=August 28, 2021}}</ref> In 2013, Gelsinger co-founded<ref name="revivalvalley/tbc">{{cite web |title=Transforming the Bay with Christ |url=https://www.revivalvalley.com/transforming-the-bay-with-christ |website=Revival Valley |access-date=6 December 2024 |date=December 5, 2014}}</ref> Transforming the Bay with Christ (TBC), a coalition of business leaders, venture capitalists, non-profit leaders and pastors that aims to convert one million people over the next decade.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Klett |first1=Leah MarieAnn |date=January 27, 2019 |title=Christianity in Silicon Valley: Meet the movement transforming the San Francisco Bay area with Christ |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/christianity-in-silicon-valley-meet-the-movement-transforming-the-san-francisco-bay-area-with-christ.html |work=The Christian Post |language=en-US |access-date=January 19, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Brigham |first=Katie |date=November 10, 2018 |title=Religious leaders are trying to get more Bay Area residents to church — and they're using tech marketing tactics in their quest |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/09/church-planting-what-it-takes-to-get-bay-area-residents-to-the-pews.html |website=CNBC |language=en-US |access-date=December 22, 2020}}</ref> He helped establish the Sacramento-area Christian institution [[William Jessup University]] from which he also received an honorary doctorate.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Pat Gelsinger |url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/author/37282165600 |website=IEEE |access-date=February 17, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220524044048/https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/author/37282165600 |archive-date=May 24, 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref> Gelsinger and his wife have 4 children.<ref>{{cite web |title=Patrick Gelsinger |url=https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/newsroom/biographies/biography-patrick-gelsinger.html#gs.jlm1mu |website=Intel |language=en-US |access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref>
